Body:
BC-PHOTO-WEEKEND-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Sunday, 10/31/99. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT22) NINGXIA PROVINCE, China -- Oct. 31, 1999 --
CHINA-POOR-2, 10-31 -- Hai Minglian, a 10-year-old who attends a
subsidized second-grade class, feeds the family ox after school in
the village of Kaicheng in the Ningxia Province. In many parts of
poor rural China, economics are keeping an increasing number of
children out of the classroom. Required fees at state schools have
grown exponentially since the central government largely stopped
subsidizing primary education a decade ago. Today education is
increasingly a luxury item, purchased only when finances allow, and
far more often for boys than for girls. (Elisabeth Rosenthal/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT21) NINGXIA PROVINCE, China -- Oct. 31, 1999 -- CHINA-POOR,
10-31 --Charitable programs in China enable some girls, like these
second graders in the village of Kaicheng, to attend classes. In
many parts of poor rural China, economics are keeping an increasing
number of children out of the classroom. Required fees at state
schools have grown exponentially since the central government
largely stopped subsidizing primary education a decade ago. Today
education is increasingly a luxury item, purchased only when
finances allow, and far more often for boys than for girls.
(Elisabeth Rosenthal/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT20) WASHINGTON -- Oct. 31, 1999 -- SMITH-PROFILE, 10-31 --
Sen. Robert C. Smith has dropped his independent run for president.
Smith's independent presidential campaign produced hardly a ripple,
and a newspaper in his home state, New Hampshire, had even asked in
an editorial, ``Where did this down-home guy get this goofy idea?''
Smith remembers the advice an old politician gave him years ago:
``There's no point getting into an argument with someone who has an
unlimited supply of ink and paper,'' he says. (Stephen Crowley/New
York Times Photo)

   (NYT19) NEW YORK -- Oct. 31, 1999 -- BABY-WRANGLERS, 10-31 --
Baby wrangler Melanie Sawyer working with photographer Rudy
LeCoadic on a cover shoot for the Millenium issue of Parents
Magazine with Nicolette Taylor, 16 months and her mother Maria. An
awful lot is riding on the tiny shoulders that the wranglers try to
keep in line. In advertising, a single photograph of a child could
form the center of a multimillion-dollar campaign. A good wrangler
can elicit the kind of reaction that pulls at parents'
heartstrings. (Andrea Mohin/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT18) LOS ANGELES -- October 31, 1999 -- SUB-AIRCRASH-REACT-3,
10-31 -- Muslim men and boys pray at the Islamic Center of Southern
California for the victims of the EgyptAir 767 that crashed shortly
after takeoff from New York south of Nantucket. The flight, bound
for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers
have found debris and human remains scattered across the sea from
the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Monica Almeida/New York
Times Photo) Sub. for correction of Moslem Center of Southern
California

   (NYT17) LOS ANGELES -- October 31, 1999 -- SUB-AIRCRASH-REACT-2,
10-31 -- A Muslim woman prays at the Islamic Center of Southern
California for the victims of the EgyptAir 767 that crashed shortly
after takeoff from New York south of Nantucket. The flight, bound
for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers
have found debris and human remains scattered across the sea from
the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Monica Almeida/New York
Times Photo) Sub. for correction of Moslem Center of Southern
California

   (NYT16) LOS ANGELES -- October 31, 1999 -- SUB-AIRCRASH-REACT-1,
10-31 -- Muslim women pray at the Islamic Center of Southern
California for the victims of the EgyptAir 767 that crashed shortly
after takeoff on Sunday from New York south of Nantucket. The
flight, bound for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late
Sunday searchers have found debris and human remains scattered
across the sea from the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Monica
Almeida/New York Times Photo) Sub. for correction of Moslem Center
of Southern California

   (NYT15) NANTUCKET ISLAND -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-RDP-7,
10-31 --Members of the U.S. Coast Guard prepare to search the
waters off the coast of Nantucket for debris of the EgyptAir 767
that crashed shortly after takeoff from New York. The flight, bound
for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers
have found debris and human remains scattered across the sea from
the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Stephen Rose/Boston Globe
Photo)

   (NYT14) NANTUCKET ISLAND -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-RDP-6,
10-31 --Nantucket police officer Anthony Santoro calls in a report
of debris spotted off the coast from the EgyptAir 767 that crashed
on Sunday 60 miles south of Nantucket shortly after takeoff from
New York. The flight, bound for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles.
As of late Sunday searchers have found debris and human remains
scattered across the sea from the airliner but no sign of
survivors. (Stephen Rose/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT13) NANTUCKET ISLAND -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-RDP-5,
10-31 --Nantucket Fire and Rescue diver Frank Hanlon looks for
debris from the EgyptAir 767 that crashed on Sunday 60 miles south
of Nantucket shortly after takeoff from New York. The flight, bound
for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers
have found debris and human remains scattered across the sea from
the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Stephen Rose/Boston Globe
Photo)

   (NYT12) NANTUCKET ISLAND -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-RDP-4,
10-31 --Nantucket Fire and Rescue divers Jeff Allen, Frank Hanlon
and Sheriff Channing Egenberg look for debris from the EgyptAir 767
that crashed on Sunday 60 miles south of Nantucket shortly after
takeoff from New York. The flight, bound for Cairo, originated in
Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers have found debris and
human remains scattered across the sea from the airliner but no
sign of survivors. (Stephen Rose/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT11) BOSTON -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-RDP-3, 10-31 --
Barry Mawn of the FBI and Rear Admiral Richard Larrabee of the U.S.
Navy brief reporters on the latest details of the EgyptAir 767 that
crashed 60 miles south of Nantucket shortly after takeoff from New
York. The flight, bound for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of
late Sunday searchers have found debris and human remains scattered
across the sea from the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Bill
Brett/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT10) NANTUCKET ISLAND -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-RDP-2,
10-31 --National Guardsmen prepare to search the waters off the
coast of Nantucket for debris of the EgyptAir 767 that crashed
shortly after takeoff from New York. The flight, bound for Cairo,
originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers have found
debris and human remains scattered across the sea from the airliner
but no sign of survivors. (Dominic Chavez/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT9) NANTUCKET ISLAND -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-RDP-1,
10-31 -- Bob Martin and Donna Fink from Westfield Mass., console
each other after hearing about the EgyptAir 767 that crashed
shortly after takeoff on Sunday from New York south of Nantucket.
The flight, bound for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late
Sunday searchers have found debris and human remains scattered
across the sea from the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Dominic
Chavez/Boston Globe Photo)

   (NYT8) NEW YORK -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-8, 10-31
-- Patrons of the Egyptian Coffee Shop in New York watch for news
about the EgyptAir 767 that crashed shortly after takeoff on Sunday
from New York south of Nantucket. The flight, bound for Cairo,
originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers have found
debris and human remains scattered across the sea from the airliner
but no sign of survivors. (Chester Higgins Jr./New York Times
Photo)

   (NYT7) NEW YORK -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-7, 10-31
-- Soheir Zaki, the Egyptian counsul general in front of the
Egyptian mission talking to reporters about the EgyptAir 767 that
crashed shortly after takeoff on Sunday from New York south of
Nantucket. As of late Sunday searchers have found debris and human
remains scattered across the sea from the airliner but no sign of
survivors. (Librado Romero/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT6) NEW YORK -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-6, 10-31
-- A woman whose brother was on the EgyptAir 767 that crashed
shortly after takeoff on Sunday from New York south of Nantucket,
is aided by police and friends upon arriving at The Ramada Plaza
Hotel at Kennedy Airport and being overcome by grief. Relatives and
friends gathered inside the hotel to console each other and receive
consolation from workers with the Red Cross, Muslim clerics and
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. The flight, bound for Cairo, originated in
Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers have found debris and
human remains scattered across the sea from the airliner but no
sign of survivors. (Michelle V. Agins/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT5) NEW YORK -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-5, 10-31
-- A woman whose brother was on the EgyptAir 767 that crashed
shortly after takeoff on Sunday from New York south of Nantucket,
arrives at The Ramada Plaza Hotel at Kennedy Airport after hearing
the tragic news. Relatives and friends gathered inside the hotel to
console each other and receive consolation from workers with the
Red Cross, Muslim clerics and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. The flight,
bound for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday
searchers have found debris and human remains scattered across the
sea from the airliner but no sign of survivors. (Dith Pran/New York
Times Photo)

   (NYT4) NEW YORK -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-4, 10-31
-- Relatives and friends arriving at The Ramada Plaza Hotel at
Kennedy Airport after hearing the news that an EgyptAir 767 crashed
shortly after takeoff on Sunday from New York south of Nantucket.
Relatives gathered inside the hotel to console each other and
receive consolation from workers with the Red Cross, Muslim clerics
and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. The flight, bound for Cairo, originated
in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers have found debris and
human remains scattered across the sea from the airliner but no
sign of survivors. (Dith Pran/New York Times Photo)

   (NYT3) LOS ANGELES -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-3,
10-31 -- Muslim men and boys pray at the Islamic Center of Southern
California for the victims of the EgyptAir 767 that crashed shortly

for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers

Times Photo)

   (NYT2) LOS ANGELES -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-2,
10-31 -- A Muslim woman prays at the Islamic Center of Southern
California for the victims of the EgyptAir 767 that crashed shortly
after takeoff from New York south of Nantucket. The flight, bound
for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers
have found debris and human remains scattered across the sea from

   (NYT1) LOS ANGELES -- October 31, 1999 -- AIRCRASH-REACT-1,
10-31 -- Muslim women pray at the Islamic Center of Southern
California for the victims of the EgyptAir 767 that crashed shortly
after takeoff from New York south of Nantucket. The flight, bound
for Cairo, originated in Los Angeles. As of late Sunday searchers

Times Photo)

   The New York Times News Service
